Self-Refine: Iterative Refinement with Self-Feedback

Aman Madaan1, Niket Tandon2, Prakhar Gupta1, Skyler Hallinan3, Luyu Gao1, Uri Alon1, Sarah Wiegreffe2, Nouha Dziri2, Peter Clark2, Shrimai Prabhumoye 4, Amir Yazdanbakhsh5, Bodhisattwa Prasad Majumder 2, Shashank Gupta2 Sean Welleck2,3 Yiming Yang1,2
1Language Technologies Institute, School of CS, Carnegie Mellon University
2Allen Institute for AI, 3University of Washington, 4NVIDIA Research, 5Google Research, Brain Team
Paper Code Data Demo

Self-Refine is a framework for iteratively improving outputs from LLMs through a process of iterative creation with feedback description.

Abstract

We present Self-Refine: a novel approach that allows LLMs to iteratively refine outputs and incorporate feedback along multiple dimensions to improve performance on diverse tasks.

The gap between text generated by humans and large language models (LLMs) is gradually closing, with LLMs now capable of producing increasingly human-like text in quality and coherence. However, there are still significant differences in how humans and LLMs approach tasks, with humans able to refine their output based on feedback and self-reflection iteratively. To bridge this gap, we introduce SELF-REFINE, a framework for iteratively improving outputs from LLMs through iterative creation with feedback. The main idea is to generate output using an LLM; then allow the model to provide multi-aspect feedback for its own output; finally, the model refines its previously generated output given its own feedback. We experiment with 7 diverse tasks, ranging from review rewriting to math reasoning, demonstrating that our approach outperforms direct generation. In all tasks, outputs generated with SELF-REFINE are preferred by humans and by automated metrics over those generated directly with GPT-3. Additionally, SELF-REFINE outperforms strong baselines in acronym generation, dialogue response generation, and code readability, improving by 21.2% absolute points. Furthermore, our framework can potentially reduce the cost of human creative processes in real-world settings by showcasing its utility in applications like iterative website design.
